texts.shortText: Tiny, short, compact and entirely wingless wasp with black body densely covered with short silvery hairs. The species is best characterized by its unique habits as an egg-parasite of the intertidal spiders Desis formidabilis and Amaurobioides africanus.

Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Appears to be confined to a small area on the Cape Peninsula, making it both extremely localised in overall distribution and highly specialised in terms of its habitat requirements.

Many scelionid wasps are eggs parasites of various arthropods and several genera parasites the eggs of terrestrial spiders. This species is unique though in that it is confined to the intertidal habitat, where it is a specialist parasite of the eggs of the Shore Spiders. The wasp appears to be highly adapted to this habitat in that it is both wingless and covered in short hairs that are though to trap a bubble of air over the body and allow the wasp to continue to breath underwater.

Over 80 % of wasps hatching are female and male wasps fight with one another for the right to mate with these females, the winners mounting the females as soon as they emerge from their eggs. Female wasps then chew their way into other compartments within the same spider egg sac and lay one egg into each of the spider eggs found there. When a female finds a batch of spider eggs about 60 of the eggs present are parasitised. Parasitised eggs turn brown as they develop, whereas un-parasitised ones remain white.
The only representative of this unusual and endemic genus and unlikely to be confused with any other species due to its unique habits.
